nodes.bodyText: each todo should have associated jira

Ack.
This TODO has been taken care in this PR, thus removed.
why do we need to add IOException now?
This get call may hit local levelDB directly or making REST call, for the latter there are more failure scenarios like network connection issues. Using IOException to capture those failure scenarios.

You don't need this function. You can just do:
ProgramType.valueOfCategoryName(programType, BadRequestException::new)
Why the rename? Is it just a refactoring to have better naming? If it is, just use the refactor rename feature in IntelliJ, it will update all callsite for you. No need to have a pending TODO

Correct. Just better naming. Didn't want to mix code refactoring with function changes, thus the todo. But actually there aren't many callsites. So just renamed.
Original intention was to have
RunRecordMeta getRunRecordMeta()
RunRecord getRunRecord()
but no need to have getRunRecord() as there is no caller.
Same here. If it is just a rename, do a refactor to update all callsite.

-                                 long start, long end, int limit) throws Exception {

nodes.bodyText: Also, if you rename the method like this, the return type should be List<RunRecordMeta>

@@ -37,6 +37,7 @@
  * includes information that should not be exposed to users. {@link RunRecord} contains fields that are exposed
  * to users, so everything else like the Twill runid should go here.
  */
+// TODO: rename RunRecordMeta to RunRecordDetail

nodes.bodyText: In the past, normally I see "metadata" terminology is used to refer to data that provides information about other data and it typically doesn't encapsulate the data it provides information for. But RunRecordMetada here extends and includes the RunRecord. So hope to use xxxDetail to name these classes that encapsulate both the data and metadata.

nodes.bodyText: Generally I would prefer as few TODO as possible in the code (you either do it now, or not to do it). I have no objection in renaming the class, but we don't need to add a TODO for it.
